body: @piiswrong

I am using your examples and following the instructions on your website. I don't think there are any instructions on how to set input data. The same input data works fine for one node. What should I do to make it visible on the distributed environment?

@eric-haibin-lin @hotpxl @tqchen @howard0su @ptrendx
try sym.BlockGrad

This is great work! Thanks a lot. I've been thinking about the need for something like this for a while.

Are you pushing everything to cuda streams as soon as they are pushed to engine? If so are you balancing the load between streams?

Another things that worries me is the use of spinlocks. This will make the scheduling threads compute intensive and compete with the data augmentation that's running on cpu. We need to benchmark the effect of this.

I'm considering changing kvstore to singleton because current implementation will break when two kvstore instances are created. Or if we could make controller a dynamic function pointer which I don't believe is possible in C++. Either way, we don't need controller and updater to be static, right?

currently, the rnn network implemented in mxnet does not support clipping operation, will this feature added in future?

how to clip gradient of cell? it seems that after computing the gradient of cell c_t, they apply clipping immediately, instead of computing the whole gradient (through the end of a sequence to the begining) and then apply clipping

Just to get a little more thought on this, the path forward should probably be a data parallel approach similar to https://github.com/timsainb/Tensorflow-MultiGPU-VAE-GAN/blob/master/VAE-GAN-multi-gpu-celebA.ipynb.  The model is duplicated across GPUs and gradients are averaged periodically.

In terms of minimally reproducible example, we could target mnist_sae.py under /root/mxnet/example/autoencoder/.  As @tokyolearninng noticed, piping in for example ctx=[mx.gpu(2), mx.gpu(3)] on ln 13, throws:


Diving into the implementation, it seems parallelism would occur in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/autoencoder/solver.py.  Will try to parse the implementation a bit better, but better documentation and comments are appreciated.

This is great. We have been discussing this for a while and this is exactly what we planned for our next generation of engine design. Here are a few general comments:

Code styles:
 - We should put thirdparty dependency on a separate folder from( preferrably thirdparty), so they can be kept in their original form
- Some naming in the code should be changed a bit to conform to google codestyle, specifically use CamelCase for functions, and stl_style for variables.
- We can have a option to switch between spinlock and mutex. I guess they might not be that different

Logics:
The real problem of such logic comes when we interleave CPU resource allocation code(which runs early) with the stream execution(which defers to the GPU),

- We need to be specifically careful about memory deletion
   - If allocator goes back to the global memory pool, it has to be sync in all the streams
   - To make imperative operation easy, we might consider add stream specific memory pool, that does not have impact on sync.

Abstraction:
Ideally, we should have an abstraction of stream, and callback in a generation way, so that we can adapt to other stream system, besides the GPU stream.
operators are already multi threaded and using all 32 cores
I meant you don't need to add an additional argument to fit to do this. You can write a callback that is a closure wrapping around eval_metric and val_metric

I can merge this right now but what we really want is binaries on the server now config file in the repo.
I'm just trying to figure out how that's going to happen
On detecting gpu, we will build separate binaries for cpu/gpu. Can snap figure out which binary to download based on whether the system has gpu?
Anyway I can merge this first if you need it merged to take the next steps.

Do you mean binary snap packages? If so, you can use https://build.snapcraft.io to create them, triggered by commits here. It's like Travis, only made specifically for creating and publishing snaps.

The "snap install" command doesn't currently give any information about GPU. We could have two separate packages, or include both sets of binaries in the same package

I see. Then I think we should move these files to mxnet-distro which is updated when ever there is a new release.
How do we configure it to build multiple binaries?

I'm happy there is interest!

I can surely write a more thorough explanation of the method. Unfortuntaly (or fortunately!) I'm getting married in two days and will be out of office for the next month, so it will have to wait a bit. I wanted to get this PR started for comments and evaluation beforehand.

@piiswrong
>Are you pushing everything to cuda streams as soon as they are pushed to engine? If so are you balancing the load between streams?

Operations are pushed to CUDA streams as soon as possible if dependencies are met, so if you push a single dependency chain of operations they will be scheduled and pushed immediately on a single stream (if there are streams available, the limit is currently set to 16 concurrent streams). If you then push another chain of operations independent of the first, it too will be scheduled and run on a separate single stream immediately. 
If any chain contains CPU operations, the first GPU part of the chain will be scheduled and pushed to a stream, the stream synchronized, the first dependent CPU operation will then be scheduled and run, the next slice of GPU operations will be scheduled and run, etc.
Load balancing is mostly deferred to the CUDA driver, scheduling actual kernels as fast as possible from different streams. The idea is to keep as much parallelism as possible so there is always work to do: bestStream() tries to achieve this.

Regarding spinlocks, I've also tried acquire/release-fence locks that yield instead of spin if busy, resulting in slightly lower performance in benchmarks. In the end I skipped this so to not have to include another lock type in the codebase, but we can of course try this if there are other advantages. The spinning of the spinlocks should be very limited though, as the locking performed is very specific - mostly around individual variables or operations.

@tqchen

For Code Styles, I can surely adjust.

Regarding resource allocation logic and interleaving CPU / GPU operations I've tried to be conservative. Only GPU operations are scheduled in bulk - other operations sync to all dependencies. It may very well be that I missed something but the engine should otherwise adhere to all expectations of the public engine API. I'm assuming that all resource allocation is scheduled in the engine as well, but my understanding of this part of MXNet is not 100% so maybe we can discuss details when I'm back.

I agree that a more general stream abstraction would be useful.

I hope to provide further updates and get the build working after my holidays.
@demingbh Should have been fixed, plz try again

build.snapcraft.io will default to building on multiple arches (x86_64, armhf and arm64 I think). It will publish them to an "edge" channel in the store that is the equivalent of daily builds, and only seen by people who specifically ask for the bleeding edge packages. They can then be tested and promoted into "beta" and "stable" channels. By default users will only see the versions published into "stable"

@bikestra I just checked source code.
1. Operator **take** has already supported gradient computation.
2. Operator **batch_take** does not support gradient computation.

We can add the gradient computation for **batch_take**.

Could you please paste your minimum reproducible python script here? Thanks.
I have solved this issue in a similar manner but but android is still not compiling due to an issue in the NDK toolchain. I am working on a fix now
Please ! any news ?

Thanks @reminisce ! Sorry for just assuming take() doesn't have gradient support.
Below is the example for computing gradients with batch_take:

```python
def test_batchtake():
    ma = mx.nd.array([[0.3, 2.0],
                      [1.0, 4.0],
                      [5.2, 6.1]])
    mb = mx.nd.array([0, 1, 1], dtype='int32')

    va = mx.sym.Variable('A')
    vb = mx.sym.Variable('B')
    vtake = mx.sym.batch_take(va, vb)
    args_grad = {'A': mx.nd.zeros((3,2))}
    executor = vtake.bind(mx.cpu(),
                          {'A': ma, 'B': mb},
                          args_grad=args_grad)
    print(executor.forward()[0].asnumpy())
    executor.backward(out_grads=mx.nd.ones(3))
    print(args_grad)
```
@bikestra Thanks for the script. I will implement it and let you know once finished.

1.as limited to the resource, there are only my pc gpu avaliable, besides in the paper，author use cpu with 16cores，see

Atari 2600 games. DQN was trained on a single Nvidia K40 GPU while the asynchronous
methods were trained using 16 CPU cores

2.I try again in the situation first set OMP_NUM_THREADS = 1,witch constrain the process will only have 1 thread, second in rl_data.py I set nthreads = 1, besides i check the cpu  occupation ratio,each python process(worker) enjoy almost same part, still don't any improvement
plus I use the same parameters without any change when the number of workers changes
But i have verified that the ufw in my ubuntu is disabled. Most importantly, I cannot see some error or any prompt messages, which perplexed me a lot and I don't know where I can start from.

I have setup this.  post here if any one want to.

first remove all nvidia packes. and reinstall xorg packs.
```
sudo apt-get purge nvidia*
sudo apt-get install --reinstall xserver-xorg-video-intel libgl1-mesa-glx libgl1-mesa-dri xserver-xorg-core
sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg
```

second install cuda8.

install cuda8  you need to 

```
crtl + alt + f1

sudo service lightdm stop

sudo init 3
```

i use cuda8 run file to install it, then installing it will prompt if you want to install nvidia card driver? 
choose yes.

it will prompt if you want to install nvidia opengl ?
choose no, this is a crucial choose, if you say "yes" here it will cover "mesa*" libraries. 

after this, choose the default.

after install, reboot, enjoy!

@szha

In order to let user create multiple `KVStore`s, I pass `*this` into `MXKVStoreRunServer` as `void *controller_handle` (so we can access the KVStore in the callback function). However, I have not tested the  runtime behavior of the code so I'm not sure if this is a valid approach. (It seems there have no c++ example uses KVStore).

I will test the runtime behavior and correctness of these code when I have time.
Problem solved

`                    data_batch = train_data.next()

                    self.forward_backward(data_batch)
                    # save grad
                    self.temp_grad = [
                        [grad.copyto(grad.context) for grad in grads]
                        for grads in self._exec_group.grad_arrays]

                    self.forward_backward(data_batch)
                    # compare grad
                    for index, pair in enumerate(zip(self.temp_grad, self._exec_group.grad_arrays)):
                        temp_grad_list, grad_arrays_list = pair
                        for k, p in enumerate(zip(temp_grad_list, grad_arrays_list)):
                            a_temp_grad, a_grad_arrays = p
                            flag = (a_temp_grad == a_grad_arrays).asnumpy()
                            flag = bool(flag.all())
                            print flag`
                   # always get the value of flag is False, why?

I forward and backward twice using the same data_batch, why did get different grads?

data_batch = train_data.next()
                    self.forward(data_batch, is_train=False)
                    output1 = self.get_outputs()[0].asnumpy()
                    self.forward(data_batch, is_train=True)
                    output2 = self.get_outputs()[0].asnumpy()
                    self.forward(data_batch, is_train=True)
                    output3 = self.get_outputs()[0].asnumpy()
                    self.forward(data_batch, is_train=False)
                    output4 = self.get_outputs()[0].asnumpy()
                    flag1 = bool((output2 == output3).all())  # false
                    flag2 = bool((output1 == output4).all())  # true
If the value of is_train is true, forward would get different output, why?

I see this is still execute and cache approach. Any consideration of utilizing python AST?

@tqchen do you mean intercepting python interpreting process?

I guess that would be too much work. It would require coding into CPython interpreter. (and will not work PyPy users).

Eventually the user interface will be just the `minpy.jit()` annotation, even in our execute-and-cache approach. I wonder if it could be any better on the user interface if we use AST. Anyways we rely on user annotation to optimize subgraph (at least for now).

Implementation-wise, we add this indirection in C-api level. I figure it would not impact performance at all.

Did you mean `X.reshape((3, 8))` in the description at the top? For reshaping from `(3, 4, 2)` to `(3, 8)`, does `reshape` with `-3` flag work for you?

As for the example in the minimum reproducible example, (i.e. reshape from `(4, 3, 2)` to `(3, 8)`. You might want to first use `swapaxes` on dimensions `0` and `1`, and then `reshape` with `-3` flag. The reason is that, if I understood it correctly, reshape itself doesn't change the layout of the data underneath, so the matrix with the new shape may not be meaningful as you intended.

You can try solution below:

KVStore name is its type actually (like `dist_sync` and `dist_async`). I believe we don't need to support multiple KVStore instances..
Yes

The definitions should be the same. There are cases where you might want two symbols:
- WarpCTC might be faster than MXNet implementation, so some users might still want to use WarpCTC (whilst MXNet version might work on more platforms)
- WarpCTC allows variable-length probability and label inputs. We might expose this in the warpctc symbol, but don't want to be bound implementing it for a future MXNet version.

If these are not major concerns, lets go with `ctc_loss`, otherwise `warp_ctc_loss`.

We register `CPDecomp3D` till `CPDecomp6D` Ops in MXNet. The forward calculation of these ops would all call `CDDecomp()` in `src/operator/contrib/tensor/cp_decomp.h`. The current code only works with MKL as BLAS/LAPACK lib.
You don't need to make 3 ops. You can get input dimensions in infershape and create operator

```c++
tensor<xpu, dim, DType> ts = in_data[0].get<xpu, dim, DType>(stream);
```

before feeding `ts` into the core function `CPDecomp()`. This line doesn't compile unless maybe we do something similar to the macro `MSHADOW_TYPE_SWITCH` but then we could only cover a finite number of cases for `dim`?
